entry.title: Case Management in SAP Service Cloud Version 2 vs. Ticket Management in SAP Cloud for Customer
entry.content:
Many customers ask us how Case Management in SAP Service Cloud V2 differs from Ticket Management in SAP Cloud for Customer (or -as many call it- SAP Service Cloud V1). Case Management in SAP Service Cloud Version 2 offers a more comprehensive and flexible framework to efficiently handle various customer inquiries and case types. Designed with an AI mindset, it supports every step of the resolution process with AI-driven automation and insights. Additionally, it provides an end-to-end process flow integrated with SAP S/4 HANA Cloud and SAP BTP, ensuring seamless service delivery and extensibility. Let’s look deeper into some of these differences.

 

 

Flexibility for Your Business Processes
One of the advantages of Case Management is the flexibility it provides in structuring work processes. You can map case types directly to your business processes, allowing customer service teams to handle diverse inquiries—such as return processes, complaint handling, or invoice inquiries—each with their own unique workflow. Whether dealing with simple or complex cases, this approach ensures that different processes are managed appropriately, guiding agents through the relevant phases and steps. This adaptability empowers service teams to efficiently navigate varied customer interactions, providing tailored solutions and improving the overall customer experience.

Easily set up different case types for effective resolution 
Creating and customizing case types in SAP Service Cloud V2 is both easy and intuitive, thanks to its user-friendly interface. Service admins can independently set up the phases and steps required for each case type without any assistance from IT. This empowers customer service teams to swiftly adapt to new situations and optimize their service processes.

Enhancing Agent Experience
Case Management in Version 2 significantly improves the agent experience by guiding them through the necessary steps of each service process, easing the onboarding of new team members. It also directs agents on what data to enter, simplifying the process and saving time. Furthermore, embedded insights and contextual data from knowledge management offer agents valuable information that aids effective issue resolution.

Smooth collaboration tools further enable service teams to work seamlessly with experts both within and outside customer service, ensuring comprehensive and timely resolution of customer issues.

Business AI Embedded Throughout the Service Process
SAP Service Cloud V2 integrates Business AI across the service process, offering a range of capabilities that enhance efficiency and effectiveness in case management. It begins at case creation, where AI assists in accurately defining the case type, ensuring inquiries are categorized correctly from the outset. As agents work on resolving cases, AI provides similar case recommendations, searching past cases for solutions to suggest, thus expediting issue resolution with informed advice. Additionally, Intelligent Q&A facilities are embedded to provide quick and relevant responses, further assisting agents in delivering timely service. These examples merely scratch the surface of the extensive AI capabilities embedded in the solution, all aimed at driving productivity and facilitating superior customer service outcomes.

Faster Resolutions, Better Agent and Customer Experience
In summary, Case Management in SAP Service Cloud V2 offers a transformative approach to customer service by reducing manual work, improving agent experience and accelerating issue resolution. This empowers service teams to adapt efficiently to diverse customer needs, leveraging flexibility, intuitive setup, and advanced AI capabilities. As a result, organizations not only enhance their service delivery but also foster stronger customer loyalty by consistently providing exceptional support. Embracing these innovations ensures that customer service operations are more agile, effective, and aligned with the demands of today's fast-paced business environment, paving the way for long lasting customer relationships driving high value for customers and the company alike.

Learn more:
If you want to see Case Management in action and hear about smooth transfer from SAP Cloud for Customer to SAP Service Cloud V2, here is a recent webcast with  that’s definitely worth watching:  Working with Case Management in SAP Service Cloud Version 2 - How to Prepare your Organization

entry.title: Re: Program to modify for avoid planned GI date update in...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

To change the behavior of the planned Goods Issue (GI) date update in SAP S/4HANA, you can utilize the Configurable Parameters & Formulas (CPF) tool to define business rules that influence the sales order process at runtime. This allows you to maintain control over the pricing date based on your specific requirements.

Steps to Configure CPF for Pricing Date

  1. Define Factory Calendar Rules: S/4HANA Q2C Sales Flexibility – Determine Requeste… - SAP Community Set up rules to determine the factory calendar, which will be used in the order process.

  2. Define Parameter Catalog for Pricing Date: S/4HANA Q2C Sales Flexibility – Determine Requeste… - SAP Community Use SSCUI to define parameters that will be used to build the CPF decision table.

  3. Define Formulas for Pricing Date: Create CPF formulas to specify how the pricing date should be determined.

  4. Assign Custom Routines to Sales Document Types: S/4HANA Q2C Sales Flexibility – Determine Requeste… - SAP Community Link the custom routine to the sales document type to ensure the pricing date is calculated according to your business rules.

  5. Test the Configuration: Create a sales order and verify that the pricing date is determined according to the rules you have set.

By following these steps, you can ensure that the planned GI date does not automatically update the pricing date unless specified by your custom business rules.

For more detailed guidance, you can refer to the SAP help documentation on flexible proposal of pricing dates.

 

 

 

[1] S/4HANA Q2C Sales Flexibility – Determine Requeste... - SAP Community
Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud Transport Management available in SAP BTP Free Tier
entry.content:
Hi Shirley,

Thank you for your question and for pointing out the documentation - we’ll update it to make this clearer.

To clarify: you don’t need a Free Tier plan for the cTMS service instance (the programmatic access), because the subscription appication-plan alone determines whether you’re on the free or paid version of cTMS.

This means, for the subscription, you choose “standard” or “free” (depending on your commercial model), while the service instance plan always remains “standard” (or export/transport_operator).

This also makes sense because you cannot fully use the service without a subscription and the associated UI access.

I hope this helps. Please let me know if you have any other questions.

Best regards,

Sven

entry.title: Re: Issue while loading maintenance order using LTMC
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

When loading a maintenance order using the LTMC template, you are encountering an error related to the operation number ‘0010’ being adapted by the system. This issue specifically occurs with the Reactive Order Type (YA01).

Possible Cause

The error might be related to the way the operation numbers are being handled in the template. In SAP systems, operation numbers should be formatted correctly, Error ‘The requested data was not found’ occurs in APP ‘Find Maintenance Task List’ - SAP S/4HANA Cloud typically as ‘0010’, ‘0020’, etc., rather than ‘010’, ‘020’. This formatting issue can lead to errors during the migration process.

Resolution

Ensure that the operation numbers in your LTMC template are formatted correctly as ‘0010’, ‘0020’, ‘0030’, etc. This aligns with the standard SAP formatting requirements and should resolve the error you are experiencing.

Additional Considerations

  • Verify that the template is correctly filled out and that all required fields are populated.
  • Check if there are any specific configurations or requirements for the Reactive Order Type (YA01) that might affect the operation number handling.

[1] Error 'The requested data was not found' occurs in APP 'Find Maintenance Task List' - SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: SAP Public cloud integration with third-party MES -ha...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

Integrating SAP S/4HANA Cloud (S4HPC) with third-party Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES) involves several key processes, especially when Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) is in use. Here is an overview of how handling units are created and how goods receipt and consumption are managed:

Handling Units Creation and Goods Receipt

Handling units are integral to various logistical processes, Handling Units in Cloud Processes including production and warehouse management. In the context of S4HPC and MES integration:

  • Production Process: Handling units are created during the production process. The raw materials required for production are reserved and, if necessary, procured through purchase orders.
  • Goods Receipt: Once production is completed, the handling units are packed and confirmed as realized. The goods receipt is posted after verification from production.

Consumption and Process Order Confirmation

For consumption, the process order confirmation API can be used. This API facilitates the confirmation of production orders, ensuring that the consumption of materials is accurately recorded.

  • Process Order Confirmation API: Manufacturing and Supply Chain in SAP S/4HANA Cloud This API is typically used to confirm the completion of production operations and the consumption of materials.

Interfaces and APIs

The integration with MES systems can leverage various APIs and interfaces:

  • Production Order Confirmation API: Used for confirming production orders and recording consumption.
  • Handling Unit Management: Handling units are managed through specific APIs that allow for their creation, modification, and tracking.

For more detailed information on the integration processes and the specific APIs involved, you may refer to the SAP documentation and community resources.

[1] Handling Units in Cloud Processes
[2] Manufacturing and Supply Chain in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: Purchasing currency in business partner.
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

Setting Default Currency for Business Partner in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the default currency for a supplier’s company code and purchasing organization data is typically set to the local currency Sourcing and Procurement - Default Options of the company code. This is a standard behavior and cannot be changed through configuration or user-specific settings.

Key Points:

  • Local Currency Default: When creating a Business Partner, the local currency of the company code is automatically used as the default currency. This is standard and cannot be altered without development.
  • Purchase Order Currency: If a purchase order with a different currency is assigned, the system will adopt the currency of the purchase order.

Options for Configuration:

  • No Standard Configuration: There is no standard configuration available to set a different default currency for the supplier’s company code and purchasing organization data without development.
  • User-Specific Settings: While user-specific settings can be adjusted for document currency in certain apps, these do not apply to the Business Partner creation process.

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Re: Distribution of AVC-objects
entry.content:
Hello @Florian83 

Thank you for your feedback and follow-up.

Avoid using Migration Cockpit for moving Variant Configuration (AVC) changes from DEV/TEST to PROD, as it’s only intended for initial loads.

In the quality system: Complete the AVC updates, including characters, classes, profiles, dependencies, and variant tables, then test and release a KB version.

Transport to Productive:

  • Key-user/AVC objects - Export Software Collection (Quality) - Import Collection (Productive).
  • CBC/SSCUI if there are any changes- Configuration Transport (Q-P).

In the productive run, consistency check and release the KB to activate the rules.

That’s the reliable, repeatable process. Migration Cockpit is not intended for continuous AVC deltas.

You can refer to the SAP below, supporting documentation

SAP help – Export Software Collection: How to package and move key-user objects between systems. SAP Help Portal-Export Software Collection

SAP Learning – Processing Transports in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Configuration Transport, Export/Import Collection, and when to use each. Learning.sap.com-Processing Transports in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

SAP help – Available Migration Objects: migration objects are built for initial migration. SAP Help-Available Migration Objects

SAP Learning – Defining Knowledge Base and Runtime Version release KB after import, so the new rules are active learning.sap. sap.com-Defining Knowledge Base and Runtime Version

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Not able to trigger the approval flow for supplier co...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

Solution for Supplier Confirmation Approval Based on Price Variance

To achieve the requirement of triggering an approval process for supplier confirmations based on a price variance compared to the purchase order (PO), you can utilize the SAP S/4HANA Cloud’s flexible workflow capabilities. Here is a step-by-step approach:

  1. Define Workflow Conditions:

    • Use the ‘Manage Workflows for Supplier Confirmations’ Manage Workflows for Supplier Confirmations app to define the start conditions for your workflow. You can set conditions based on supplier, company code, purchasing organization, and document type.
    • Specifically, you need to define a condition that checks for a price variance exceeding 5% or $750.

  2. Implement Custom Logic:

    • Since runtime values for calculations are not directly available in the BAdI, you can implement custom logic using the BAdI ‘Enhancement of Flexible Workflow Properties’.
    • This BAdI allows you to define rules for agent determination and can be used to exclude certain agents from receiving approval tasks.

  3. Use BAdI for Agent Determination:

    • Implement the BAdI ‘Procurement: Agent Determination in Flexible Workflow’ Procurement: BAdi for Agent Determination in Flexible Workflows to determine the approvers based on your custom conditions.
    • You can use the purchasing document number and workflow scenario as input parameters to fetch the necessary data for your calculations.

  4. Configure Workflow Steps:

    • Define the sequence of steps in your workflow, including the recipients and preconditions.
    • Ensure that the workflow step is marked as mandatory, so the approval process is enforced.

  5. Testing and Validation:

    • Test the workflow by creating a supplier confirmation with a price variance and ensure that it triggers the approval process.
    • Validate that once approved, the PO value is updated accordingly.

By following these steps, you can effectively manage supplier confirmations that require approval due to price variances, ensuring that the PO values are only updated post-approval.

Kind regards, 
Henrike

[1] Manage Workflows for Supplier Confirmations
[2] SAP S/4HANA Cloud - Flexible Workflow with new custom pre-condition for

entry.title: Re: How to Dynamically Change the Task Title in Workflow...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

To dynamically change the task title in the Purchase Requisition workflow notifications, you can use custom logic by implementing a BAdI (Business Add-In). This approach allows you to define custom pre-conditions and step conditions that can include dynamic data such as the description or name of the Purchase Requisition.

Steps to Implement Custom Logic:

  1. Implement BAdI for Custom Pre-Conditions: SAP S/4HANA Cloud - Flexible Workflow with new custom pre-condition for

    • Use the BAdI SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF to define new pre-conditions or step conditions.
    • You can specify dynamic data fields such as the Purchase Requisition description.

  2. Evaluate Custom Conditions:

    • Implement the BAdI SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_EVAL to evaluate the conditions against the Purchase Requisition.
    • This BAdI allows you to check the values dynamically and set the task title accordingly.

  3. Configure Workflow:

    • Use the ‘Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions’ app to set up the workflow with the newly defined conditions.

By following these steps, you can customize the task title to include dynamic data from the Purchase Requisition, such as its description or name.

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Re: Can 'Display Changes to Objects' be used to view the...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question and sorry for the late reply.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue?

To view the scheduling agreement price change history in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you can use the ‘Price Change Scheduling Agreements’ feature. This allows purchasers to change a supplier’s prices in info records, contracts, or scheduling agreements, provided they have time-dependent conditions.

Steps to View Price Change History

  1. Access the App: Use the ‘Manage Purchasing Info Records’ app to access the scheduling agreements.

  2. Select Criteria: Enter the purchasing organization, supplier, and other selection criteria.

  3. Specify Price Change Type: Choose whether the price change relates to the gross price or a specific condition type.

  4. Define Validity: Set the validity period for the price change using the ‘Conditions valid from/to’ fields.

  5. Execute Changes: Initially, changes are simulated. To implement them, cancel the ‘Test run’ selection and execute the program.

  6. View Changes: The old and new prices are displayed with the validity period. Save the changes.

For more detailed instructions, you can refer to the SAP Help Portal documentation on ‘Price Change Scheduling Agreements’.

If you are looking for a specific feature in the ‘Display Changes to Objects’ app, it might not directly support scheduling agreement price changes as per the current options available.

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: Last Indicator Value in Line Monitor POD within SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Hi @brunocechella 

Whenever an asset with indicators have been updated since they have been previously subscribed to via Last Indicator Plugin, it is required that the indicator metadata store is refreshed. 

Such changes include:

  • Adding new indicators
  • Removing indicators
  • Renaming indicators
  • Changing indicator datatype

The scenario experienced by you is likely the latter and a quick refresh should resolve their problem.

To refresh indicator metadata:

  1. Open any Line Monitor POD (or Custom POD containing that Last Indicator Value Plugin) in the POD Designer
  2. Navigate to the Last Indicator Value Plugin (Typically found in the Asset Details Page)
  3. Select the plugin and click on the Gears icon on the top of the screen to open its configuration properties
  4. Click on “Configure Indicators”
  5. Click on the refresh button on the upper-right hand corner of the Configure Indicators dialog

 

Can you try the same and let me know ? 

 

Thanks,

Marcel

entry.title: Leveraging Asynchronous Request-Reply Pattern for Order Management Foundation (OMF)
entry.content:
As part of our ongoing efforts to improve system performance, scalability, and user experience, we are introducing a shift in how some of our SAP Order Management Services (OMS) APIs handle requests — moving from a synchronous to an asynchronous request-reply pattern. In this article, we will explore how this pattern has been used for the SAP Orders V3 API and Returns API functionality.

Until now, when you performed a POST operation (e.g., creating a sales order), the system processed the request immediately and returned either a success with the object details or an error. While simple, this approach has limitations — especially under high load or during peak processing periods, where response times may increase or requests may fail due to timeouts. Failing to do so may negatively impact the customer experience and result in unfavorable financial outcomes.

Why this change?

  • Improved perceived performance: Faster initial responses for your users
  • Higher reliability: Reduced risk of timeouts or retry storms
  • Scalable architecture: Better handling of large request volumes

Using this pattern, the API will respond immediately with a confirmation and an object ID, while the actual processing continues in the background. Therefore, we can reduce the latency even further while providing two options (push or pull) for the API caller to determine the final status of each request.

 

Evolution

Orders V2 already delivers the key functionalities our customers need for most e-commerce use cases. Based on customer feedback and our study of how it is used, we identified areas for improvement: scalability and availability.

Figure 1. High-level representation of V2 processing flow

To address those, we revised the architecture of the API to leverage asynchronous processing as much as possible. With these changes, we reduce the number of tasks that happen during the initial API call, providing you with faster response times and deferring more expensive calls to an asynchronous flow.

Figure 2. High-level representation of V3 processing flow.

 

Migration

The new version keeps backward compatibility for the order creation API contract. This means you will continue to use the same payload as of today, simply updating the URL endpoint to indicate the new version.

Upon receiving the request, the system will perform an initial validation, and you will now receive a 202 response code if the basic validation was successful or 4xx/5xx . It is a small change as Order V2 currently returns 201 upon success.

Since we are now deferring some of the additional tasks to an asynchronous flow, you are required to check the order status using one of the two mechanisms described below:

  1. [RECOMMENDED] Subscribe to Order Events via Event Hub

In this mechanism, you subscribe to the Order Events to identify if there were any failures while creating the Order and react accordingly.

Figure 3. Subscribing to Event Hub events to be notified of Order updates.

As part of this release, we are now emitting two new events:

  • Order Created
  • Order Retriggered

And we have a new version of the Order Canceled event.

    2. Establish polling for order updates

In this mechanism, you periodically poll for order updates until the status is indicative of success or failure.

Figure 4. High-level representation of polling solution for V3.

As soon as the order is placed, it will be PENDING, and once you get the status TRANSFER_SUCCESSFUL*, it means you are sure the order has no additional issues and will be processed, as it happens with V2.

We recommend an exponential backoff mechanism for the polling, which should be adjusted according to your specific use case. For example:

T0

 Order Placed, 202 received

T1

 100ms

T2

 200ms

T3

 400ms

T4

 800ms

T5

 1600ms

…

 

If we can’t successfully perform all the asynchronous tasks, the order will be in a failed state when you perform the get order call.

 

Handling Failures

Independent of which method you choose, there are cases where we will face errors.

In these cases, we recommend you assess the reason why it failed – available as part of the event or API payload – and decide on the next action. That may be repeating the API call from the client side (e.g., from a web shop) or notifying the customer by email, informing them of the failure that took place.

 

Conclusion

Asynchronous Request-Reply pattern is a powerful way to reduce the latency for APIs and increase the resilience of your integrations.

You send the request, for example, to create an Order or a Return, and the API will perform the minimal set of operations, returning quickly if any permanent error is found.  If all is well, processing begins behind the scenes and will have two options to be informed of the processing: polling or subscribing to the events and reacting to new ones.

This EventHub subscription option will be available with the release of the Orders V3 API, and is coming soon to the Returns API.

*  The actual status may differ based on your specific business configuration

entry.title: Re: Custom field in EPPM WBS structure
entry.content:
Hello @FranciscoCosta 

Thank you for your question. The screenshots are very helpful.

You are addressing two separate issues:

1st, Value resets on the project header

Your field is created in the WBS (Project Element) business context, so it saves on PRPS only. The project header PROJ has nowhere to store it - it snaps back to 0.

Fix: create a second field in the Project header context and enable it in UIs and the Reports and If you want the header to reflect WBS progress, add a small derivation avg/max/weighted in Custom Fields & Logic on the Project header.

2nd, The report shows the maximum everywhere

Analytics is treating your numeric field as a measure and aggregating it.

Fix: in Custom Fields & Logic - field - General Information, set Aggregation to None or Average if that’s your logic.
Then, in your custom query/report, set the field’s Exception Aggregation to None/Average accordingly. Republish and refresh.

Use the Checklist below;

  • Create a Project header field and keep the existing WBS field.
  • Enable both under UIs and Reports for the apps/cubes you use.
  • Set proper aggregation, republish, and refresh the report cache.
  • (Optional) Add roll-up logic from WBS - Project.

Refer to the SAP documentations below;

SAP Help Portal – Creating Custom Fields & enabling for UIs and Reports

SAP Help Portal – Custom Analytical Queries (Fiori app): Measures & Exception Aggregation

Let me know if it works

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Medical device stock to clinic and traceability for p...
entry.content:
For your business case, you need to explore SD with CS/PM modules as detailed below which is just my rough suggestion as I have not worked in this process.

  • First you need to create an equipment record for each serialized device via IE01.
  • You can create a consignment fill-up and an outbound delivery, for the devices sent to clinics/hospitals. Here you need to track the serialized devices using equipment master records. For that, go through this blog by @mohan_kaliyamoorthy  You can monitor the device in consignment stock via MB58.
  • Consider creating Consignment Pick-up when the device is returned.
    Now create a Service Order via IW31, update the equipment status like "Returned", "Ready for reuse". Go through this SAP guide blog by @Shakeel_Ahmed1 on Serialization and Batch Management. Here, link the equipment number to the order for traceability. You can name the service activities as Data extraction or Report download
  • Once the download is completed, you can confirm the service order via IW42. This step records the actual work done and prepares the system for billing.
  • Finally, create a billing document based on the service confirmation. Of course, here, the billing document have only the details of service confirmation and you dont have visibility to device. So link the billing document to the equipment via some custom fields.

If the patients are not tracked via SAP, then, consider using custom partner function to represent them. For insurance billing, extend the partner determination to include the insurance company as Payers.

I am not sure the above steps would work but if it works, please test it thoroughly from inventory angle and financial postings.

We are planning S/4HANA foundation conversion from Netweaver 7.52 to S/4HANA Foundation, for which only SAP LTRS FOR SAP S/4HANA is supported. Is it compatible to have DMIS 2018 SP08 on sender system and SLT on DMIS 2018_1_752 SP 12?

entry.title: Re: SAP SLT compatibility to S/4HANA foundation
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

 

As you can see in note 0002675613 - SLT (DMIS 2010 / DMIS 2011 / DMIS 2018 / DMIS 2020 / S/4HANA) Installation, Corrections and Release Information:

SAP LTRS 1.0 is equivalent to DMIS 2020 and DMIS 2020 is always identical to a respective DMIS 2018 SP released at the same time (see SAP Note 2965075). In this case DMIS 2020 SP08 is equivalent to DMIS 2018 SP12 - details in note 0003438948 

So yes, you environment will be compatible. 

 

Thank you, 

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: In the scope item 5D2,why a company have to create tw...
entry.content:
To answer your question "My question is why a company have to create two business partner?", BP created with the vendor roles like FLVN00 & FLVN01 is used in intercompany supplier invoices. That is, when the delivering company bills the selling company. In your case, it is BP B1 represents Company B as a vendor to Company A.

BP created with the customer roles like FLCU00 & FLCU01 is used in intercompany customer invoices. That is, when the selling company posts the intercompany receivables. In your case, it is BP A2 represents Company A’s plant as a customer to Company B.  This separation ensures that financial postings are correctly aligned with the legal entities involved, not just the logistics locations.

Now coming to the other point, why one BP is not enough, please note Plants and Company codes serve different roles in intercompany flows. The delivering plant must be linked to a sales area and a customer BP for intercompany billing. The receiving company code must be linked to a vendor BP for supplier invoice posting. This is especially important in cross-company code sales, where the intercompany invoice is posted to the customer BP representing the plant and the intercompany supplier invoice is posted to the vendor BP representing the company code.

entry.title: Case Management: Preconditions in Case Flow Steps
entry.content:
Prerequisite:

A draft case type version.

Introduction:

Preconditions in case flow steps define the rules that determine when a step can be performed. By configuring preconditions, administrators gain fine-grained control over the flow execution, ensuring that certain steps become actionable only when the specified conditions are met.

As the name suggests, a precondition is a requirement that must be satisfied before a step can be acted upon. During case updates or when the case flow is updated, these conditions are continuously evaluated until they are fulfilled for the steps of the current phase. Once a precondition is satisfied and the step is enabled for action, it remains valid, meaning the system will not re-check it to disable the step later, even if the condition is no longer satisfied.

This mechanism ensures that business processes remain consistent, predictable, and aligned with organizational rules, while also offering administrators the flexibility to design intelligent and conditional workflows.

Examples:

The following examples highlight a few possible use cases of case flows with preconditions, showing how they help streamline processes, enforce business rules, and enhance efficiency in case management:

1) Triggering Feedback Loop:

Consider a customer support case where an organization wants to capture customer satisfaction after case completion. A precondition can be configured such that the “Trigger Feedback Survey” step can be executed only if the case is completed and for certain customer interaction channel. Once the conditions are satisfied, the feedback flow is actionable. This ensures feedback is collected only from genuine resolved cases, avoids sending irrelevant surveys, and improves both customer experience and the quality of insights gathered.

2) Approval in Refund Cases:

In a customer refund case, an approval step may be required before processing. A precondition can be configured so that the “Manager Approval” step to be enabled only if the refund amount exceeds certain amount or the customer is flagged as high-risk. This ensures that standard refunds are processed quickly without delays, while large or sensitive refunds go through additional oversight, balancing both efficiency and control.

3) Creating Service Order:

In a field service request case, a technician may need to be dispatched to resolve a customer issue. A precondition can be configured so that the “Create Service Order” step is triggered only if the case type is “Service Request”, the case category is “Technical Issue”, and required details (diagnostics, address, and contact information) are available. This ensures that service orders are created only for valid service-related cases, avoiding unnecessary technician dispatch for billing or inquiry cases, thereby improving operational efficiency and resource utilization.

Configuration:

The steps below demonstrate how to configure a precondition for a To-Do step, and the same steps can be applied to all step types.

1. Open a draft case type version in detail view

 2. Navigate to Case Flow tab

3. Click on Create Step button which shows the list of step types that can be created.

 4. You can choose any step type to add a precondition. In this example, we’ll configure the preconditions for a To-Do step.

5. Fill in all the required fields in the step creation form, then click the Create Preconditions button in the Pre-conditions section. 

 6. A modal popup appears, allowing you to add preconditions based on Case entity attributes.

 7. Click the first dropdown to select a Case entity attribute, then add a condition based on that attribute. In this example, let’s select Status. The dropdown also includes any extension fields created for the Case entity.

8. The second dropdown displays the possible operators based on the selected Case entity attribute. In this example, let's select Equal operator.

 9. The last input box allows the user to enter a value for the selected Case entity attribute. In this example, let's select In Process status.

 10. Click the plus (+) button to add another condition within the same condition group.

 11. Select one of the two options: ANY or ALL. If you select ANY, the condition group is considered true if at least one condition within it is true. If you select ALL, all conditions must be satisfied for the condition group to be true.

 12. To add a new condition group, click the New Condition Group button.

 13. Between condition groups, you can choose the condition operator AND or OR. If you select AND, the entire condition is true only when all condition groups are true. If you select OR, the entire condition is true if any one of the condition groups is true.

14. Once the conditions are configured, click the Save button to save the preconditions.

In this example, we have configured the following condition: the To-Do step will be enabled for processing only when the status code is In Process and the case is created for a priority customer, or when the case is escalated.

15. The configured precondition is displayed in the Pre-conditions section, where it can be edited or deleted.

 16. Click on Create button to create the step.

 17. Fianlly, activate the draft case type version. The case type is ready, allowing you to create a case where you can observe the effect of the preconditions.

Preconditions in Action for Different Step Types:

The case type used for this example is Preconditions in Case Flow Step (ZPCS)

To-Do Step:

Step name: Collect Customer Data

Precondition configured: The To-Do step will be enabled for processing only when the status code is In Process and the case is created for a priority customer, or when the case is escalated.

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step, and the Set Step to Done button, which completes the step, is disabled.

Satisfy the precondition by either escalating the case or changing the status to In Process and marking the priority customer flag as true. In this example, we will escalate the case. Once the precondition is satisfied, the step is enabled for processing, allowing the agent to mark it as complete by clicking the Set Step to Done button.

De-escalate the case to make the precondition unsatisfied; the step will still remain processable. Preconditions act as entry conditions.

Input Step:

Step name: Collect Data

Precondition configured: The Input step will be enabled for processing only when the status of the case is In Process.

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step, and both the Set Step to Done button (which completes the step) and the Save button (which saves the input step form) are disabled. The entire form is also disabled, preventing agents from entering any values.

Satisfy the precondition by updating the status to In Process. Once the precondition is met, the entire form is enabled for the agent to enter values, and the Set Step to Done button becomes active. After the agent fills in the form, the Save button is also enabled. Even if the precondition becomes unsatisfied later, the step remains processable.

Approval Step:

Step name: Refund Approval

Precondition configured: The approval process will be enabled when the refund amount exceeds 5000$

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step, and Submit Approval Request button is disabled. 

The approval step gets enabled if the refund amount exceeds 5000$. Even if the precondition becomes unsatisfied later, the step remains processable.

Feedback Step:

Step name: Request Feedback

Precondition configured: The Feedback step will be enabled, allowing it to be sent to the reporter of the case once the case is completed. 

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step. The Feedback step is designed to send automatically once the current phase is completed, provided its preconditions are satisfied; therefore, no buttons specific to the Feedback step will be shown.

Satisfy the precondition by changing the status to Completed. The Feedback step is now enabled to be sent automatically when the current phase is completed.

The Feedback step can also be configured to be manually triggered by the agent once the precondition is met. In the example below, since the precondition is not satisfied (same precondition configured - feedback request can be send once the case is completed), the Submit button remains disabled. 

Satisfy the precondition by changing the status to Completed. The Feedback step is now enabled to be sent manually by clicking Submit button.

Action Step:

Step name: Create Service Order

Precondition configured: Automatically create a service order if repair is required.

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step. The Action step is executed automatically once the precondition is met, without any agent intervention; hence, no button is displayed for this step.

Once the precondition is satisfied by setting the ‘Requires Repair’ flag to true, the service order is created automatically.

If no precondition is configured for the Action step, it executes automatically as soon as the phase containing the step changes to In Progress.

The Actions step allows admins to configure a step that performs actions such as creating a Task, Opportunity, Service Order, Sub-Case, Sales Quote, Lead or calling an external hook automatically.

Assignment Step:

Step name: Set the ‘Requires Repair’ flag

Precondition configured: Set the ‘Requires Repair’ flag when the case is created as a service request.

 Assignment action configured: Set the ‘Requires Repair’ flag

Create a case using case type ZPCS and open it in the detailed view. Since the precondition is not met, an informational message appears at the top of the step. The Assignment step is executed automatically once the precondition is met, without any agent intervention; hence, no button is displayed for this step.

Once the precondition is satisfied by updating the subject to include 'SERVICE_REQUEST', the Assignment step executes and updates the case.

The Assignment step allows admins to configure a step to modify case property values. The properties to be updated are added as assignment actions, as shown below.

If no precondition is configured for the Assignment step, it executes automatically as soon as the phase containing the step changes to In Progress.

All step types can be executed even without preconditions; configuring a precondition is optional.

Conclusion:

Preconditions in case flow steps provide a flexible and powerful way to control the execution of steps within a case. They act as entry conditions, ensuring that each step becomes actionable only when the specified criteria are met. This allows organizations to enforce business rules, streamline processes, and maintain consistency while offering administrators the ability to design intelligent, conditional workflows.

While preconditions enhance control, all step types—including To-Do, Input, Approval, Feedback, Action, and Assignment steps—can still execute without them, making precondition configuration optional. By strategically leveraging preconditions, organizations can improve operational efficiency, reduce errors, and ensure that steps are triggered only when appropriate, without requiring unnecessary agent intervention.

entry.title: Re: Custom field in EPPM WBS structure
entry.content:
Hello @FranciscoCosta 

That’s perfectly understandable!Numeric custom fields can only use Sum, Max, and Min options in Custom Fields Logic.

How to get what you want:

  • Average or no roll-up: In Custom Analytical Query, set the measure’s Exception Aggregation to Average, select a Reference Characteristic such as WBS/Project, or None.
  • Never aggregate utilise a text mirror field for display, or compute and persist the header value on Project (PROJ) via Custom Fields & Logic.

If you have further questions, let me know

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Preq created with PDT & GR Proc. time from material m...
entry.content: It has been observed that your MRP run is using Scheduling = 1, which means MRP performs basic scheduling. It calculates dates using material master PDT and GRPT. It does not read the info record or contract lead times, even if they exist and are valid. This is standard ECC behavior. To make MRP consider the info record PDT, you must run MRP with Scheduling = 2 → Lead time scheduling and routing. For any reasons, if this Scheduling Parameter cannot be changed to 2, then, you can go for custom validation via BAdI MD_PURREQ_POST

entry.title: SAC Story Filter API | On Change Event
entry.content:
Dear all,

I am currently working on a SAC story that consumes a BW query via live connection. The query is designed to rely solely on story filters and variables from the BW live model.

However, we’ve encountered a strange issue with a time variable. When opening the story and providing an initial input value, everything works as expected. But if we change the prompt while the story is already open, the numbers do not update. The only way to reflect the new values is by refreshing the page and restarting the story—this allows us to enter a new input value, and then the correct data is displayed.

 

In summary, changing the prompt within the story has no impact on the on-the-fly calculations. It appears that no request is sent to BW unless the story is reloaded with the desired variable value.

Has anyone experienced something similar?

My proposed solution was to capture the click on the story or variable filter, track the change, and then trigger a story refresh. However, this approach is problematic since story filters do not support an onChange event. Reopening the story every time the timestamp needs to be changed is not a user-friendly solution.

Do you have any alternative ideas or workarounds to address this issue?

Best regards,

entry.title: IPS provisioning to ABAP Cloud Developer Trial
entry.content:
This is my test in setting up IPS to provision user and groups to my Cloud ABAP developer Trial system which is on my home docker.

My test scenario, I have

  1. A Cloud Identity Service in US East region
  2. my BTP subaccount in US East region
  3. Subscribed to Cloud Identity Services Connectivity Plan in my BTP subaccount
  4. I have my Abap Cloud Developer 2023 trial system running on docker
  5. Configured the Cloud Connector in the docker to connect to my BTP subaccount

Since I don’t have a Corporate iDP proxied in my Cloud Identity Service (SCI) , I will use the SCI identity stored as my iDP (user store)  and IPS source.  The goal is to be able to provision the user and groups in IAS into my ABAP Cloud Identity.

So, roughly it will look like this.

 

This is important for IPS to be able to access the RFC destinations in that subaccount. The subaccount needs to be in the same region as the IPS tenant.

Note that trial version of Cloud Identity Services will not work with on-premise as it does not come with "Connectivity plan". See blog.

Some notes about SCI plans.

  • 3326943 - Cloud Identity Services - Plan Type
  • 3211854 - "Connectivity Plan" is not visible in BTP Service Marketplace
  • 3537257 - Error occurred when subscribing default/additional/connectivity plan for Cloud Identity Service

The rest of the configuration, follow the sap help documentation that provided a concise step by step procedure that includes setting up IAS/Cloud Connector/Tenants/ABAP role/ABAP Technical user/RFC Destinations:

How to connect Identity Provisioning with IAS as the source and S/4 HANA On-Premise as the target

Instead of repeating the steps, I'll put screenshots of my setup.

My Setup Screenshots

BTP Subaccount

 

SCI connectivity plan subscribed.

Cloud Connector on docker

Cloud Connector is available in BTP subaccount

 

Cloud Connector is active

Subaccount RFC Destination to Cloud ABAP on-premise

 

IPS Source:

 

In my example, ias.user.filter parameter is used to filter to just one test user.

The recommendation is to filter based on your needs and not provision every groups and users,  which might overwhelm the ABAP system with unnecessary users.  

IPS Target:

 

 

 

Lessons learned:

  1. Cloud Identity Service must not be NEO. 
  2. Subaccount tenant for the on-premise system must be in the same region as the Cloud Identity Service.
  3. Connectivity Plan is needed for the subaccount with the on-premise RFC destinations.
  4. IAS group provisioned as Business Role in ABAP, not in SUGR. The business Role must exist in ABAP for it to be provisioned to the user.
  5. IAS user must have a Login Name. This is mapped to user field in SU01.

 

Hopefully these learnings and screenshots will help the community.

entry.title: Re: issues with user name in LMS system
entry.content: @Surya_Sai_Rani, check if the User Connector/User Connector - SF didn't update the user's name after its run. Even if you change the user's name via the Import Data feature, connectors can overwrite it on the next run. It'd be required to adjust the user's name on the source system.

entry.title: Re: End-to-end Testing using Peppol Exchange in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition
entry.content:
@Yannik1 - I ran into this same phone & email issue on initial testing.  I edited the node 105651 in Manage Your Solution (or CBC) to include both the Phone and Email with valid values in the Address > Communication section in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, extended edition .  Below is error code I saw

Peppol (German requirements) mandate that you include both a phone and an email, along with an address.  You need to go to that node 105651 Edit Address for Company Codes. Select the Company and Address button.  Then make sure the phone, email and address data is complete in the Address > Communications section. I also had a fatal error on missing payment terms which sit on BP/customer.  On Payable side, if you're receiving an invoice, the Supplier would need to include their phone and email fields too. Or they can't send a Peppol invoices to Accounts Payable or in our case, Concur Invoice, if there is no phone or email specified.

entry.title: SAP Developer News September 4th, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION

PODCAST: https://podcast.opensap.info/sap-developers/2025/09/04/sap-developer-news-september-4th-2025/↗

SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers

  • SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers to enable agentic development for Enterprise Applications: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-build-introduces-new-mcp-servers-to-enable-agentic-development-for/ba-p/14205602
  • Introducing the MCP Server for CAP: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/boost-your-cap-development-with-ai-introducing-the-mcp-server-for-cap/ba-p/14202849
  • First Release of the SAP Fiori MCP Server for Agentic AI Workflows: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-fiori-tools-update-first-release-of-the-sap-fiori-mcp-server-for/ba-p/14204694
  • Introducing the UI5 MCP Server: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/give-your-ai-agent-some-tools-introducing-the-ui5-mcp-server/ba-p/14200825
  • AI agents talk at SIT Porto: https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7358844307413393408/

ABAP Partner Reference Application

  • ABAP Partner Reference Application: https://github.com/SAP-samples/abap-partner-reference-application?tab=readme-ov-file

Step-by-step guidance to extend Joule via Joule Studio in SAP Build (Live Session)

  • Step-by-step guidance to extend Joule via Joule Studio in SAP Build (Live Session): https://learning.sap.com/live-sessions/step-by-step-guidance-to-extend-joule-via-joule-studio-in-sap-build

 

CHAPTER TITLES

0:00 Intro

0:10 SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers

2:28 Step-by-step guidance to extend Joule via Joule Studio in SAP Build (Live Session)

3:06 ABAP Partner Reference Application

 

TRANSCRIPTION

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for September 4th, 2025.

[Witalij] If you see me wearing this T-shirt, you can be sure it's about AI. And you are absolutely right. This announcement has been wildly shared this week, but in case you missed it, we at SAP have introduced MCP servers to bring the Model Context Protocol into enterprise application development. The emerging open standard Mobile Context Protocol defines how large-language models can access tools and project context in a secure and structured way. Three servers are now available. For the Cloud Application Programming Model, for SAP Fiori Elements, and for SAPUI5. Let's double-click on each of them. The CAPMCP server has been released as open source under the Apache 2.0 license. It provides two tools for AI-assisted development of CAP applications, one to search across the compiled CDS model and one to search the CAP documentation. The Fiori MCP server lets AI agents generate and edit Fiori applications, discover apps in the workspace, and follow built-in rules that enforce best practices. This speeds up prototyping and makes iterations easier. The server is actually available as an experimental release. The UI5 MCP server equips your AI agents with six tools. This range from best practice guidelines and product scaffolding to searching the API reference, linking code and fixing deprecated APIs, providing insights into the project details. By releasing the CUP server as open source and extending MCP to Fiori and UI5, we are building an ecosystem where AI agents can actively support enterprise development. To learn more, we invite you to explore the CAP MCP server on GitHub, try out the UI5 and Fiori Elements servers in your own projects, and share your feedback on SAP community. And be sure to follow upcoming updates in SAP Build Code to see how Joule continues to expand MCP-based scenarios. By the way, if you are interested in AI agents, this month I will be presenting this very topic at SAP Meetup in Luz, in Poland, and at SAP Insight Track in Porto, Portugal. See you then.

[Nora] I have some great news for our listeners with a Learning Hub subscription, because the AI advocacy team is hosting a live session called Step-by-Step Guidance to Extend Joule by Joule Studio in SAP Build. It's going to take place on the 16th of September at 11 Central European Summertime, 11 a.m. It's targeted at developers. It's going to be a hands-on session that will teach you everything you need to know about Joule Studio, how to build your custom skills, how to integrate it into other systems, and how to test and deploy your skill. And it's targeted at beginners. So make sure you sign up and learn from the experts themselves.

[M K, Sheena] By leveraging the SAP BTP ABAP environment and the ABAP RESTful Application Programming model, you can build applications side-by-side to SAP solutions such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud. This GitHub repository provides a sample partner reference application called Music Festival Manager to build, deploy, and run side-by-side multi-tenant applications based on the SAP EVTP APAC Cloud to extend and integrate with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These applications ensure SAP standards for enterprise-grade business solutions and also offers a consistent, harmonized user experience. The advantages include a clean code for a page safety, a scalable cloud development model, and secure integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud. In addition to the step-by-step tutorial, it also includes sizing guides, build materials, best practices, and tools for building multi-tenant extensions. Check out the GitHub repository link in the description box below and start building your enterprise create SaaS applications today.
